         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>BATS FROM SOUTHEASTERN ASIA 131</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Andersen (1905 : 126) recorded R. minor (= pusillus) from Darjeeling, Thailand<tei:lb/>and Java. As Osgood (1932 : 215) pointed out, when Andersen wrote further on the<tei:lb/>pusillus group (1918 : 376) and named R. blythi blythi and R. b. szechwanus, evidently<tei:lb/>he had concluded that the mainland forms were separable from pusillus of Java.<tei:lb/>Indeed, Andersen has re-labelled the specimens in the British Museum (Natural<tei:lb/>History) on which the continental records of pusillus were based as 'szechwanus'.<tei:lb/>Osgood considered that specimens obtained in Cochin China (South Vietnam) by<tei:lb/>Delacour and Lowe (B.M. 28.7.1.18-19) and referred to pusillus by Thomas were<tei:lb/>doubtless closely related if not identical to R. blythi calidus Allen, 1923, to which<tei:lb/>Osgood referred a specimen from Tonkin (North Vietnam), suggesting that since the<tei:lb/>distinctions between the various forms seemed unclear it might be preferable to<tei:lb/>treat them as races of pusillus, the earliest name. There is every probability,<tei:lb/>therefore, that Rhinolophus pusillus Temminck, 1834 must replace R. blythi Andersen,<tei:lb/>1918 if this is thought to be specifically distinct. Ellerman and Morrison-Scott<tei:lb/>(1951 : 117) considered R. blythi a subspecies of R. cornutus Temminck, 1835, to<tei:lb/>which Van Peenen, Ryan &amp; Light (1969 : 61) allocated specimens from South and<tei:lb/>North Vietnam (presumably those reported by Osgood) and from Thailand. How-<tei:lb/>ever, Wang et al. (1962 : 556, 558, 568) reported R. cornutus pumilus Andersen, 1905<tei:lb/>and R. blythi (as a species) from Kwangsi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>^ Rhinolophus acuminatus acuminatus Peters, 1871<tei:lb/>Malaya : Kuala Kenarong, Ulu Perak. , $ B.M. 73.609-610.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhinolophus acuminatus has remained unreported from Malaya although there is a<tei:lb/>number of records from Thailand, Laos and Cambodia (Hill &amp; Thonglongya, 1972 :<tei:lb/>185), and the species occurs also on Sumatra and the nearby islands of Engano and<tei:lb/>Nias, on Borneo, Java and on Lombok. Like those from Thailand and Laos<tei:lb/>previously reported, these Malayan specimens agree closely in size with R. a.<tei:lb/>acuminatus from Java. Both have been preserved in alcohol. The female is very<tei:lb/>similar in colour to reddish brown examples from Java, its dorsal surface brown,<tei:lb/>tinged with russet, especially posteriorly. Ventrally it is greyish brown, the hairs<tei:lb/>pale based, pale grey brown for much of their length and extensively tipped with<tei:lb/>grey. Dorsally, the male is browner, lacking russet, lightly tipped over the shoulders<tei:lb/>with silver grey : ventrally it is paler than the female, more nearly fawn, with a<tei:lb/>brownish tinge.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements ($ B.M. 73.609, $ B.M. 73.610) : length of forearm 49-1, 47-8 ;<tei:lb/>width of noseleaf 8-1, 8-0 ; greatest length of skull to canine 21-5, 20-5 ; condylo-<tei:lb/>canine length 19-2, 18-2 ; width across nasal swellings 6-1, 5-8 ; least interorbital<tei:lb/>width 2-5, 2-7 ; zygomatic width n-6, 11-3 ; width of braincase 9-0, 9-0 ; mastoid<tei:lb/>width 10-2, 9-9 ; c 1 -c 1 5-6, 6-0 ; m 3 -m 3 8-3, 8-3 ; c-m 3 8-6, 8-0 ; length of complete<tei:lb/>mandible 15-2, 13-7 ; c-m 3 9-2, 8-8.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The subspecies of R. acuminatus as they are defined by Andersen (1905 : 132,<tei:lb/>1906 : 657) seem separable only by relatively small features. Mainland specimens<tei:lb/>have the lower part of the lateral margins of the sella more or less parallel as in</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>132 J. E. HILL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>acuminatus from Java and in audax from Lombok, the sella not abruptly widened<tei:lb/>basally as in sumatranus from Sumatra or circe from Nias, or in calypso from Engano<tei:lb/>in which the sella, although widened, is less so than in these but which has a very<tei:lb/>wide noseleaf. There seem no consistent size differences between the subspecies :<tei:lb/>a series from Java suggests a degree of sexual dimorphism in size, with females<tei:lb/>tending to be a little smaller than males.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Myotis horsfieldii horsfieldii (Temminck, 1840)<tei:lb/>Sulawesi : Wawondula, south Sulawesi. $ B.M. 73.1804.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This is the first of Myotis horsfieldii to be reported from Sulawesi, the species<tei:lb/>being known otherwise from Java, Borneo (Medway, 1965 : 60), Malaya and perhaps<tei:lb/>Thailand (Hill, 1972 : 31). For the present it is referred to the nominate subspecies :<tei:lb/>cranially it corresponds to or slightly exceeds the upper limits of size for Javan<tei:lb/>specimens as represented in London, but these derive from a single series from one<tei:lb/>locality. It is similar in size to the larger of Bornean specimens (M. h. lepidus<tei:lb/>(Thomas, 1915)) but no more than three examples of this subspecies are available.<tei:lb/>Medway (1965 : 60) suggests that lepidus from Borneo may be distinguished from<tei:lb/>Javan horsfieldii by slightly shorter skull and slightly narrower braincase, conditions<tei:lb/>not supported by the available specimens. The condylobasal length of eighteen<tei:lb/>Javan specimens ranges from 13-2 to 14-7, in three from Malaya from 13-7 to 14-3<tei:lb/>and from 14-3 to 14-7 in three from Borneo : the width of the braincase varies from<tei:lb/>6-9 to 7'4 in Javan examples, from 6-9 to 7-3 in those from Malaya and from 7-1 to<tei:lb/>7-3 in the specimens from Borneo, which include the holotype of lepidus. The<tei:lb/>Bornean subspecies appears therefore to be only weakly if at all separable.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements of the specimen from Sulawesi : length of forearm 37-7 ; greatest<tei:lb/>length of skull 15-7 ; condylobasal length 14-4 ; condylocanine length 13-8 ; least<tei:lb/>interorbital width 3-6 ; zygomatic width ; width of braincase 7-4 ; mastoid<tei:lb/>width 8-0 ; c^c 1 4-2 ; m 3 -m 3 6-0 ; c-m 3 5-7 ; length of complete mandible 11-3 ;<tei:lb/>c-m 3 6-2. The registration numbers of Malayan specimens measured by Hill<tei:lb/>(1972 : 31) are incorrectly assigned. The measurements cited are of B.M. 61.2133<tei:lb/>(forearm only), B.M. 65.320, B.M. 65.321, and of $ B.M. 16.4.21.16 (this number<tei:lb/>omitted) from Batu Burong, Pahang, in that order.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>^ Pipistrellus circumdatus (Temminck, 1840)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Java : Cibodas ( = Tjibodas), Cianjur, west Java, o645' S, I07oo' E, at 1350 m.<tei:lb/>&lt;$. Original number 1435. Bogor Museum No. 10069 ( a * present at United<tei:lb/>States National Museum of Natural History, the Smithsonian Institution,<tei:lb/>Washington) .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kandang Badak, Cianjur, west Java, o647' S, io659' E, at 2425 m. &lt;$. Original<tei:lb/>number 1761. U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit No. 2, Djakarta Detachment.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Situ Gunung, Sukabumi (= Soekaeboemi), west Java, o65o' S, I0755' E, at<tei:lb/>1000 m. $. B.M. 73.1805.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Malaya : Telecommunications Tower, Eraser's Hill, Pahang. ^ B.M. 73.618.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>BATS FROM SOUTHEASTERN ASIA 133</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Extant specimens of the poorly known south-east Asian species Pipistrellus<tei:lb/>circumdatus (Temminck, 1840) were briefly reviewed recently by Hill (1972 : 189),<tei:lb/>who described a closely related species, P. societatis, from Malaya. At that time, no<tei:lb/>more than five examples of P. circumdatus were known.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although Temminck (1840 : 215) remarked that Boie and Macklot, who first<tei:lb/>obtained the species in the Tapos district of Java, sent several individuals to the<tei:lb/>Musee des Pays-Bas (the Rijksmuseum van Natuurlijke Historic, Leiden), the<tei:lb/>catalogues by Jentink (1887 : 277 ; 1888 : 178) of that collection report only a single<tei:lb/>specimen, in 1887 as 'one of the types of the species' for the skull, and in 1888 as<tei:lb/>'type of the species' for the mounted specimen to which the skull belongs. This<tei:lb/>specimen remains in the Rijksmuseum van Natuurlijke Historic : a second example<tei:lb/>from Java, now in the collection of the British Museum (Natural History) (B.M.<tei:lb/>7.1.1.401) is from the collection of R. F. Tomes, and since this collector obtained<tei:lb/>specimens from many sources, including the major museums of his day, it is possible<tei:lb/>that it is one of the original specimens obtained by Boie and Macklot.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Known continental specimens are limited to three. One, (B.M. 61.12.10.1) in<tei:lb/>the collection of the British Museum (Natural History), is of uncertain provenance.<tei:lb/>It came from T. C. Jerdon and is said by Blanford (1891 : 312) to have originated<tei:lb/>from southern India. Another (A.M.N.H. 114850), in the American Museum of<tei:lb/>Natural History, is from Pyepat, Upper Burma, and has been reported by Anthony<tei:lb/>(1941 : 81), Tate (1942 : 250) and by Hill (1972 : 36). The third, listed above, from<tei:lb/>Eraser's Hill, Pahang, Malaya, was briefly reported by Hill (1972 : 36, footnote). It<tei:lb/>is therefore of particular interest to record three specimens from Java obtained by<tei:lb/>the United States Medical Research Unit No. 2, Djakarta Detachment, and to present<tei:lb/>a more detailed account of the newly collected Malayan specimen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The specimens from Java agree closely with the description by Temminck and with<tei:lb/>B.M. 7.1.1.401. The males are exactly similar in colour to this example, the blackish<tei:lb/>brown dorsal pelage finely but profusely tipped with shining orange or bronze, the<tei:lb/>ventral pelage dark brown, the hairs lightly tipped with grey except on the flanks<tei:lb/>where the tipping is brownish, sometimes faintly orange. The membranes are<tei:lb/>black and in B.M. 7.1.1.401 evidently have faded to a browner shade. The female<tei:lb/>specimen has dorsal pelage a little less finely tipped with orange, the individual<tei:lb/>orange hair tips slightly more extensive to give a coarser effect : its ventral surface<tei:lb/>resembles the ventral surface of the other specimens although the tips of the hairs<tei:lb/>tend to be more yellowish buff, especially anteriorly. Cranially, the specimens con-<tei:lb/>form closely to B.M. 7.1.1.401, described, with the skull of the holotype of circum-<tei:lb/>datus, in the account already published (Hill, 1972 : 36).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The example from Malaya is very similar to the Burmese specimen (A.M.N.H.<tei:lb/>114850) discussed by Hill (1972 : 36), its skull differing slightly in a number of features<tei:lb/>from the skulls of Javan specimens. It is generally a little smaller ; the cranial<tei:lb/>crests are less prominent, the supraorbital ridges slightly less evident but in this<tei:lb/>example not terminating in slight tubercles ; the frontal depression is a little shal-<tei:lb/>lower but the post-palatal extension is not shorter than in the Javan skulls as is the<tei:lb/>post-palatal extension of the Burmese example. As in the Burmese specimen, the<tei:lb/>post-palatal spine is narrow : although broken in two of the Javan skulls examined,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>I 34 J- E - HILL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>in the other two skulls from Javan specimens the spine is more broadly based. There<tei:lb/>is little difference in the dimensions of the teeth, although the canines of the Malayan<tei:lb/>specimen are very slightly less massive than are those of the Javan examples.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Initially, a comparison of the Burmese specimen with Javan material suggested<tei:lb/>(Hill, 1972 : 36) that the mainland and Javan populations might be subspecifically<tei:lb/>distinct. The new material confirms that small differences exist between the two<tei:lb/>populations but as yet insufficient specimens are available for any definite conclusion<tei:lb/>to be drawn. The Malayan specimen is of especial interest since it demonstrates the<tei:lb/>presence of P. circumdatus in Malaya with the newly described P. societatis, a closely<tei:lb/>similar species differing chiefly in smaller size, particularly of the rostrum, palate<tei:lb/>and dentition, and in its short post-palatal region (length of bony post-palate in<tei:lb/>four Javan specimens of circumdatus 1-5-1-7, in the Malayan specimen 1-7, in the<tei:lb/>holotype of societatis (B.M. 67.1605) i.i).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements ($ 1435, 3 1761, ? B.M. 73.1805 from Java, $ B.M. 73.618 from<tei:lb/>Malaya, in that order) : length of forearm 41-2, 41-1, 42-1, 40-5 ; greatest length of<tei:lb/>skull 16-0, 16-3, 16-6, 15-5 : condylobasal length 15-7, 15-7, 16-0, 14-9 ; condylo-<tei:lb/>canine length 15-4, 15-4, 15-7, 14-7 ; palatal length (excluding the post-palatal spine)<tei:lb/>8-4, 8-4, 8-6, 8-0 ; length palatal bridge (excluding the post-palatal spine) 6-5, 6-6,<tei:lb/>6-8, 6-4 ; length orbit-gnathion 4-2, 4-0, 4-2, 4-1 ; lachrimal width 7-1, 7-2, 7-3, 7-2 ;<tei:lb/>width across supraorbital tubercles or swellings 6-6, 6-6, 6-7, 6-4 ; zygomatic width<tei:lb/>11-4, , 11-7, ; least interorbital width 4-2, 4-4, 4-3, 4-3 ; width of braincase 8-0,<tei:lb/>8-1, 8-1, 7-9 ; mastoid width 8-7, 8-7, 9-1, 8-5 ; c 1 -^ 5-2, 5-3, 5-4, 5-0 ; m 3 -m 3 ,<tei:lb/>7-6, 7-7, 7-3 ; c-m 3 6-2, 6-1, 6-3, 5-9 ; length of complete mandible , 11-9, 11-9,<tei:lb/>n-i ; c-m 3 6-5, 6-4, 6-7, 6-3.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Philetor brachypterus verecundus (Chasen, 1940)<tei:lb/>Malaya : Ulu Gombok, Selangor. &lt;$ B.M. 73.597.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genus Philetor with its sole species P. brachypterus is known from New Guinea,<tei:lb/>Malaya, Sumatra and, doubtfully, from Java and Banka (Hill, 1971 : 140). Its<tei:lb/>occurrence in Malaya was based initially on two female specimens from Perak<tei:lb/>originally described as Eptesicus verecundus by Chasen (1940 : 53), one the holotype<tei:lb/>collected on Mount Kledang by Dr R. Hanitsch (now B.M. 47.1437) and the other<tei:lb/>(at one time in the collections of the former Raffles Museum, Singapore) from an<tei:lb/>unspecified locality in that State. Medway (1969 : 35) mentions that it has<tei:lb/>been collected in Selangor. Eptesicus verecundus was transferred to Philetor<tei:lb/>by Hill (1966) who considered it a subspecies of Philetor rohui Thomas, 1902 from<tei:lb/>New Guinea : later, the same author (1971) referred Vespertilio brachypterus Tem-<tei:lb/>minck, 1840 from Sumatra to Philetor as a third subspecies, brachypterus taking<tei:lb/>precedence as the specific name.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This further specimen of P. b. verecundus has been donated to the collections of the<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History) by Dr D. R. Wells of the School of Biological<tei:lb/>Sciences, the University of Malaya. Its muzzle, ears and tragus agree closely with<tei:lb/>those of the holotype : the structure of the penis, hitherto unknown in verecundus,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>BATS FROM SOUTHEASTERN ASIA 135</tei:p>
         <tei:p>is almost exactly like that of P. b. rohui (figured by Hill, 1966 : 375, fig. i), differing<tei:lb/>only in slightly wider and deeper fissures in the ventral part of the glans.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cranially there is close agreement with the holotype of verecundus. The braincase<tei:lb/>is very slightly more inflated than in P. b. rohui as it is in the holotype : the narial<tei:lb/>emargination, however, rather wider at the roots of i 2 ~ 2 and broadly V-shaped<tei:lb/>apically in the holotype of verecundus, is in this specimen rather narrower and more<tei:lb/>rounded at the apex, thus conforming with rohui and with the holotype of P. b.<tei:lb/>brachypterus from Sumatra (Hill, 1971 : 141). The upper canines of the specimen<tei:lb/>from Selangor are a little more massive than in the holotype of verecundus, and the<tei:lb/>Selangor specimen differs from this and from rohui in having a narrow rather than<tei:lb/>wide post-palatal spine, and its basioccipital pits are a little less prominent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements : length of forearm 35-9 ; greatest length of skull ; condylobasal<tei:lb/>length 14-7 ; condylocanine length 14-3 ; lachrimal width 6-7 ; width across ante-<tei:lb/>orbital foramina 5-5 ; least interorbital width 4-6 ; zygomatic width ; width of<tei:lb/>braincase 8-3 ; mastoid width 9-0 ; c^c 1 5-4 ; m 3 -m 3 6-7 ; c-m 3 4-8 ; i 2 -m 3 5-6 ;<tei:lb/>length of complete mandible 10-4 ; c-m 3 4-9.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Miniopterus medius macrocneme Revilliod, 1914<tei:lb/>Sulawesi : Wawondula, south Sulawesi. $, &lt;$ B.M. 73.1806-1807.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The length of the forearm and tibia, with the globose, high braincase and slender<tei:lb/>canines refer these specimens to M . medius, hitherto unreported from Sulawesi.<tei:lb/>They display the less massive dentition characteristic of the easterly subspecies<tei:lb/>M. m. macrocneme which until now has not been known to occur further west than<tei:lb/>the islands of Ambon and Ceram, in the Molucca Islands.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements ($ B.M. 73.1807, $ B.M. 73.1806) : length of forearm 44-4, 43-3 ;<tei:lb/>length of tibia 19-1, 18-8 ; greatest length of skull 13-7 ; 13-2 ; condylobasal length<tei:lb/>13-1, 12-9 ; condylocanine length 12-6, 12-1 ; least interorbital width 3-4, 3-5 ;<tei:lb/>zygomatic width 7-4, 7-5 ; width of braincase 7-4, 7-2 ; mastoid width 7-6, 7-5 ;<tei:lb/>c 1 -^ 1 3-9, 3-7 ; m 3 -m 3 5-4, 5-4 ; c-m 3 5-1, 5-0 ; length of complete mandible 9-7,<tei:lb/>9'5 ; c-m 3 5-6, 5-3.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phoniscus atrox Miller, 1905<tei:lb/>Malaya : Tekom Forest Reserve, Jerantut, Pahang. &lt;$ B.M. 71.1135.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Until recently P. atrox was known in the literature from the holotype from Sumatra<tei:lb/>and from two further examples reported from southern Thailand by Kloss (1916 : 12).<tei:lb/>The first record for Malaya is of a subadult from the Ulu Gombok Forest Reserve,<tei:lb/>Selangor, at 2000 ft, reported by Medway (1969 : 43). This second Malayan speci-<tei:lb/>men agrees exactly with those from southern Thailand.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements : length of forearm 34-2 ; greatest length of skull 15-5 ; condylo-<tei:lb/>basal length 13-7 ; condylocanine length 13-7 ; least interorbital width 3-8 ;</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>136 J. E. HILL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>zygomatic width 8-7 ; width of braincase 7-0 ; mastoid width 7-4 ; c^-c 1 3-6 ;<tei:lb/>m 3 -m 3 5-5 ; c-m 3 6-0 ; length of complete mandible 10-5 ; c-m 3 6-5.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tadarida johorensis (Dobson, 1873)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Malaya : Pulai, Kelantan, 4^8' N, ioi57' E, c. 780 ft. &amp;J (n subadult) B.M.<tei:lb/>73-632, 636, 638-642, 647, 649-651, $$ (6 subadult) B.M. 73.633-635, 637, 643, 644,<tei:lb/>646, 648.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Extant accounts of T. johorensis are based on one or other of two specimens. The<tei:lb/>detailed descriptions by Dobson (1876 : 180, 183, fig. a ; 1877 : 718, 726, fig. 5 ;<tei:lb/>1878 : 421, 432) refer to the holotype from Johore, Malaya. Later, Andersen<tei:lb/>(1907 : 39, 44) described a further specimen from Soekaranda, Deli, Sumatra and<tei:lb/>gave an account of the features of its skull and dentition. These remained apparently<tei:lb/>the only known specimens until Chasen (1940 : 59) recorded the species from Selangor,<tei:lb/>Malaya and from the island of Sri Buat, off the east coast of Johore. More recently,<tei:lb/>Medway &amp; Yong (1969 : 33) have recorded the material from Kelantan on which<tei:lb/>these notes are based, but as T. plicata.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dobson and Andersen in their descriptions of this species emphasize the large<tei:lb/>interaural pocket which can be closed by an extension of the interaural band. The<tei:lb/>inner or anterior margins of the ears are joined by a thick, deep band of integument<tei:lb/>originating from a low transverse ridge on the muzzle, its upper margin elevated<tei:lb/>between the ears in a truncately triangular flap. Posteriorly the lower part of this<tei:lb/>band forms the anterior wall of a deep subtriangular or subquadrangular pocket<tei:lb/>between the ears, its lateral walls more or less parallel and its posterior wall a low,<tei:lb/>slightly curved ridge. The pocket is divided by a low median septum and contains<tei:lb/>a few long hairs at the bottom of its anterior part : otherwise the integument forming<tei:lb/>and surrounding the pocket is naked or nearly so. The free upper part of the<tei:lb/>interaural band is convex anteriorly, hollowed posteriorly, and forms a lid or cover<tei:lb/>to the pocket. Previous descriptions of this structure refer only to the male. The<tei:lb/>interaural box in two adult females from Kelantan exactly resembles that of the adult<tei:lb/>male : there is little variation among the younger examples in the series but in these<tei:lb/>the posterior wall of the pocket is sometimes less prominent and the pocket a little<tei:lb/>shallower than in the older specimens. The dorsal pelage of specimens (in alcohol)<tei:lb/>from Kelantan is uniformly mid-brown, the hairs paler at the extreme base. The<tei:lb/>ventral pelage is predominantly fawn but is browner at the flanks, this shade extend-<tei:lb/>ing also to the sides of the throat.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tadarida johorensis is very similar to T. plicata from which it differs chiefly in the<tei:lb/>presence of the interaural pocket. The small cranial differences separating the two<tei:lb/>species are admirably summarized by Andersen (1907 : 40) and are confirmed by an<tei:lb/>adult female from the series from Kelantan. These are the absence of marked<tei:lb/>cranial ridges in johorensis, its low, ill-defined sagittal crest terminating more pos-<tei:lb/>teriorly and not extending on to the supraorbital region, with the facial foramen<tei:lb/>placed farther posteriorly immediately above the narrowest part of the postorbital</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>BATS FROM SOUTHEASTERN ASIA 137</tei:p>
         <tei:p>constriction ; a low rostrum in johorensis, with straight or slightly concave rostral<tei:lb/>profile which contrasts with the more inflated, convex profile of plicata ; a shallow<tei:lb/>narial emargination in johorensis which extends posteriorly to a line joining the<tei:lb/>anterior margins of the anteorbital foramina ; the upper incisors are shorter and<tei:lb/>more massive in johorensis which has shorter upper canines and smaller anterior<tei:lb/>premolars (pmf), with the principal cusp of the second upper premolar (pm 4 ) less<tei:lb/>developed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements of adult specimens from Kelantan (&lt;$ B.M. 73.636, $ B.M. 73.635<tei:lb/>(forearms only), $ B.M. 73.637) : length of forearm 46-7, 49-2, 46-4 ; greatest length<tei:lb/>of skull 19-6 ; condylobasal length 17-3 ; condylocanine length 16-7 ; least inter-<tei:lb/>orbital width 4-6 ; zygomatic width 11-2 ; width of braincase 9-9 ; mastoid width<tei:lb/>10-6 ; c 1 -^ 1 4-7 ; m 3 -m 3 8-2 ; c-m 3 6-8 ; length of complete mandible 12-5 ; c-m 3<tei:lb/>7'3-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SUMMARY</tei:p>
         <tei:p>New records of bats from the mainland and islands of south-eastern Asia include<tei:lb/>the first reports of Rhinolophus pusillus Temminck, 1834 (probably conspecific with<tei:lb/>R. blythi Andersen, 1918, which it antedates) from Malaya and the island of Tioman,<tei:lb/>and of R. acuminatus acuminatus from Malaya. Chironax melanocephalus, Myotis<tei:lb/>horsfieldii horsfieldii and Miniopterus medius macrocneme are recorded for the first<tei:lb/>time from Sulawesi. Further specimens of Pipistrellus circumdatus are recorded<tei:lb/>from Java and the first Malayan example of this species is reported in detail. The<tei:lb/>first male specimen of Philetor brachypterus verecundus is described from Malaya and<tei:lb/>a further specimen of Phoniscus atrox reported from that country. A series of<tei:lb/>Tadarida johorensis from Kelantan is reported and establishes the presence of the<tei:lb/>interaural pocket, hitherto known only from the adult male, in female and young<tei:lb/>examples.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>THE HAPLOCHROMIS SPECIES<tei:lb/>(PISCES : CICHLIDAE) OF LAKE RUDOLF,</tei:p>

         <tei:p>THE BULLETIN OF THE BRITISH MUSEUM</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(NATURAL HISTORY), instituted in 1949, is<tei:lb/>issued in five series corresponding to the Departments<tei:lb/>of the Museum, and an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts will appear at irregular intervals as they<tei:lb/>become ready. Volumes will contain about three or<tei:lb/>four hundred pages, and will not necessarily be<tei:lb/>completed within one calendar year.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In 1965 a separate supplementary series of longer<tei:lb/>papers was instituted, numbered serially for each<tei:lb/>Department.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This paper is Vol. 27, No. 3, of the Zoological<tei:lb/>series. The abbreviated titles of periodicals cited<tei:lb/>follow those of the World List of Scientific Periodicals.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation :<tei:lb/>Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Zool.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1974</tei:p>
