      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE HAPLOCHROMIS SPECIES<tei:lb/>(PISCES : CICHLIDAE) OF LAKE RUDOLF,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EAST AFRICA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CONTENTS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Page</tei:p>
         <tei:p>INTRODUCTION ........... 141</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis rudolfianus ... ...... 142</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis turkanae sp. nov. ........ 150</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis macconneli sp. nov. ....... 154</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION ........... 161</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS ......... 164</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REFERENCES ........... 164</tei:p>
         <tei:p>INTRODUCTION</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LAKE RUDOLF is outstanding amongst the Rift Valley Great Lakes of Africa for the<tei:lb/>paucity of its endemic cichlid species, and particularly for the absence of a Haplo-<tei:lb/>chromis species flock (Trewavas, 1933). Whereas all other large Rift Valley lakes<tei:lb/>have a well-defined flock of endemic Haplochromis species (even if, like Lake Albert,<tei:lb/>the flock comprises only a few species), Lake Rudolf was thought to possess but a<tei:lb/>single Haplochromis species, the endemic H. rudolfianus Trewavas, 1933. The lake's<tei:lb/>one positive ichthyological peculiarity, the presence of an endemic species belonging<tei:lb/>to the west African genus Pelmatochromis, has now been shown to stem from a<tei:lb/>misidentification. The Rudolf Pelmatochromis is, in fact, a specimen of the wide-<tei:lb/>spread taxon Hemichromis bimaculatus Gill (see Trewavas, 1973).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Endemicity amongst the non-cichlid species is also at a low level (see Worthington<tei:lb/>&amp; Ricardo, 1936 ; personal observations on collections recently made in the lake).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Various ideas have been advanced to explain the absence of a Haplochromis<tei:lb/>species flock in Lake Rudolf (see summaries and comment in Fryer and lies, 1972).<tei:lb/>Of these, the most likely would seem to be the relative youth of the present lake<tei:lb/>fauna, an invasion from the Nile in post-Middle Pleistocene times. Coupled with<tei:lb/>this factor are the shape and recent history of the lake basin, neither of which would<tei:lb/>provide opportunities for the isolation (and subsequent speciation) of populations<tei:lb/>living in the lake. That until now the only Haplochromis known to inhabit the<tei:lb/>lake was of a structurally and ecologically generalized type similar to the fluviatile<tei:lb/>species of eastern Africa, would seem to agree with such a postulated lake history.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Recently, however, a second and anatomically specialized species has been dis-<tei:lb/>covered in the deeper waters of the lake. A few specimens of a third species (similar<tei:lb/>to H. rudolfianus, see p. 150) have also been collected, and there are indications of<tei:lb/>yet another taxon (see p. 149).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>These and other specimens, made available through the efforts of the Lake Rudolf<tei:lb/>Fishery Research Project, have provided sufficient material to describe the new<tei:lb/>deep-water taxon, the new Haplochromis rudolfianus-like fish, and to redescribe in</tei:p>
         <tei:p>i*</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>i 4 2 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>greater detail H. rudolfianm itself. Unfortunately the putative fourth species is<tei:lb/>represented by so few and distorted specimens that I consider it inadvisable to<tei:lb/>describe it at present. Nevertheless, sufficient information has been gathered from<tei:lb/>these few specimens to show that this species too is like H. rudolfianus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As part of a planned review of phyletic relationships within the Haplochromis-<tei:lb/>group cichlids, some consideration is also given to the relationships of the Lake<tei:lb/>Rudolf species with those of other lakes, especially Lakes Albert and Victoria.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis rudolfianus Trewavas, 1933</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Text-figs. 1-4)<tei:lb/>Haplochromis rudolfianus Trewavas, 1933, /. Linn. Soc. (Zool.), 38 : 321-322.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LECTOTYPE. A specimen, 51-0 mm standard length (BMNH reg. no. 1933.2.23 :<tei:lb/>163), from a weedy lagoon on the east shore of Lake Rudolf, near Mt El Moitat<tei:lb/>(station number 285, see Worthington, 1932). The specimen has been eviscerated,<tei:lb/>but judging from its preserved coloration it is probably an adult male.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PARALECTOTYPES. Three specimens (BMNH reg. nos. 1933.2.23 : 164-166),<tei:lb/>39-0-42-5 mm S.L., from the same locality as the lectotype (all are eviscerated),<tei:lb/>and one other specimen (BMNH reg. no. 1933.2.23 : 167), 45-0 mm S.L. from<tei:lb/>Central Island (Worthington's station no. 264). This latter fish is also eviscerated<tei:lb/>but is probably an adult male.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Comment on the original description of H. rudolfianus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trewavas' (1933) original description was based on 5 syntypes, but 25 other<tei:lb/>specimens were also examined although not included in the description. I have<tei:lb/>re-examined these fishes and would confirm their identification as H. rudolfianus.<tei:lb/>Dr Trewavas also included in this species, but with certain reservation, a larger<tei:lb/>specimen, 61-0 mm S.L. and 80 mm total length (BMNH reg. no. 1933.2.23 : 169).<tei:lb/>The locality label for this fish reads '? Lake Rudolf, the uncertainty stemming from<tei:lb/>the collector's notes on the provenance of the specimen. A number of differences<tei:lb/>between this fish and other specimens of H . rudolfianus were noted by Trewavas. I<tei:lb/>can confirm these differences and would add others. The size discrepancy once<tei:lb/>existing between this specimen and others of H. rudolfianus is virtually obliterated<tei:lb/>by the larger specimens of the latter species now in the Museum's collections. Thus<tei:lb/>it seems very unlikely that the various differences listed by Trewavas are, as she<tei:lb/>then suggested, size correlated ones.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The specimen in question departs from H . rudolfianus in having a deeper body<tei:lb/>(37' 4 P er cent of standard length), somewhat deeper preorbital (17-7 per cent of<tei:lb/>head length), wider interorbital distance (25-6 per cent of head), a deeper cheek<tei:lb/>(25-6 per cent of head), a smaller eye diameter (30-0 per cent of head) and a markedly<tei:lb/>shorter caudal peduncle (14-7 per cent of standard length, cf. 16-5-19-7, mean<tei:lb/>18-0 per cent in H. rudolfianus) . The fish also differs from specimens of H. rudolfianus<tei:lb/>in having fewer gill rakers (7 cf. 8 or 9), larger scales on the nape and in the lateral<tei:lb/>line series (30), in lacking the characteristic dark vertical bars on the body and caudal</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>LAKE RUDOLF HAPLOCHROMIS SPECIES 143</tei:p>
         <tei:p>peduncle (see p. 147), in having no melanic pigment in the ovarian walls (see p. 146)<tei:lb/>and in having stouter and somewhat obliquely cuspidate outer jaw teeth. The lower<tei:lb/>pharyngeal bone is finer than in H. rudolfianus, and the median lower pharyngeal<tei:lb/>teeth are also finer (see p. 146).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In my opinion, this specimen cannot be identified as a member of H. rudolfianus,<tei:lb/>nor can it be placed in either of the other Haplochromis species from Lake Rudolf.<tei:lb/>All the evidence certainly suggests that it in fact belongs to the fauna of another<tei:lb/>lake. On this assumption, the specimen was compared with Haplochromis species<tei:lb/>from all the lakes sampled by the Cambridge University Expedition of 1930-31. It<tei:lb/>cannot be identified with any known Lake Albert Haplochromis species, nor does it<tei:lb/>closely resemble any of the described (or known but undescribed) species of Lakes<tei:lb/>Edward and George ; see Greenwood, 1973. It does, however, closely agree in all<tei:lb/>morphometric and anatomical features (especially the dentition) with H. velifer<tei:lb/>Trewavas of Lake Nabugabo, Uganda (see Greenwood, 1965). Since extensive<tei:lb/>collections were made in this lake by the Cambridge Expedition, I would identify<tei:lb/>the fish as a specimen of H. velifer and suggest that the locality label be altered to<tei:lb/>read 'Lake Nabugabo'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The redescription of H. rudolfianus given below is based on the 5 type specimens<tei:lb/>(39'0-5i-o mm S.L.) and 20 additional fishes (30-5-58-0 mm S.L.) collected in 1972<tei:lb/>by the Lake Rudolf Fisheries Research Project team at Topi point, Allia Bay, and<tei:lb/>Ferguson's Gulf. Coloration and certain anatomical details were also checked on<tei:lb/>the other specimens from which meristic and morphometric data were not taken<tei:lb/>(BMNH reg. nos. 1973.11.13 : 151-170).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All counts and measurements used in this description are those defined by Green-<tei:lb/>wood (1973).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal head profile straight or gently curved, sloping at an angle of 25-30 degrees<tei:lb/>with the horizontal ; premaxillary pedicels rarely breaking the smooth outline of the<tei:lb/>profile.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of head 31-0-35-3 (mean, M = 33-5) per cent of standard length, depth<tei:lb/>of body 29-4-33-7 (M = 32-1) per cent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Preorbital depth 12-5-17-9 (M = 15-0) per cent of head, least interorbital width<tei:lb/>20-0-27-4 (M = 22-7) per cent, neither dimension showing allometry with standard<tei:lb/>length. Length of snout 26-6-32-3 (M = 29-9) per cent of head, 0-7-1-1 (mode 0-8)<tei:lb/>times its breadth. Eye diameter 30-5-35-7 (M = 32-9) per cent of head (showing<tei:lb/>ill-defined negative allometry), depth of cheek 17-4-25-8 (M = 21-7) per cent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal peduncle 16-5-19-7 (M = 18-0) per cent of standard length, 1-2-1-7<tei:lb/>(modal range 1-3-1-5) times as long as deep.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mouth horizontal or slightly oblique. Length of upper jaw 30-8-38-0 (M = 33-7)<tei:lb/>per cent of head, length of lower jaw 35-7-48-3 (M = 39-7) per cent, 1-4-1-8 (modal<tei:lb/>range 1-5-1-7) times as long as broad. Posterior tip of maxilla reaching a vertical<tei:lb/>through the anterior margin of the eye.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gill rakers. Relatively stout, with the lower i or 2 on the first gill arch reduced ;<tei:lb/>9 (less frequently 8, rarely 10) on the lower limb of that arch. Well-developed<tei:lb/>'pseudorakers' (fleshy protuberances between the inner and outer row of true rakers)<tei:lb/>are present on the first arch.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. i. Haplochromis rudolfianus. Lectotype. Drawn by Gordon Howes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scales. Strongly ctenoid, those on the anteroventral aspects of the thoracic<tei:lb/>region very small, with an abrupt size transition between them and the posterior<tei:lb/>scales of this region. Immediately anterior to the first dorsal fin spine there is a<tei:lb/>small naked area (about i| or 2 scales in area), and often there is also a narrow naked<tei:lb/>strip below the ventral horizontal row of cheek scales. Lateral line with 30 (f2),<tei:lb/>31 (fio), 32 (fi2), or 33 (fi) scales, cheek with 3 (rarely 2 or 4) rows. Six or 7 scales<tei:lb/>between the dorsal fin origin and the upper lateral line, 6 or 7 (rarely 5) between the<tei:lb/>pectoral and pelvic fin bases.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fins. Dorsal with 24 (fi2), 25 (fn) or 26 (f2) rays, comprising 14 (f3), 15 (121)<tei:lb/>or 1 6 (fi) spinous and 9 (19), 10 (fi5) or n (fi) branched rays. Anal with 3 spinous<tei:lb/>and 8 (13), 9 (f2o), 10 (fi) or n (fi) branched rays.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First branched ray of the pelvic fin very slightly produced in both sexes, but rela-<tei:lb/>tively more so in adult males.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal subtruncate, scaled on its basal quarter to third.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Teeth. The majority of teeth in the outer row of both jaws are unequally bicuspid<tei:lb/>and moderately stout (Text-fig. 2) ; the major cusp is acutely pointed and equilateral<tei:lb/>in outline. A few unicuspid teeth sometimes occur posteriorly in the upper jaw, but<tei:lb/>more often the posterior teeth are tricuspid ; rarely are these teeth bicuspid. A<tei:lb/>noteworthy feature of the samples examined is the pronounced wear pattern seen<tei:lb/>on the outer teeth. Worn teeth have the major cusp either obliquely truncate or<tei:lb/>the wear may be so great that all demarcation between major and minor cusps has<tei:lb/>disappeared and the crown is spatulate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are 28-48 teeth in the outer premaxillary row, the number showing some<tei:lb/>positive correlation with the fish's length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All inner row teeth are small tricuspids, and are arranged in 2 or 3 (mode), rarely 4,<tei:lb/>rows in the upper jaw and in 2 (mode) or 3 rows, rarely a single row, in the lower jaw.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>LAKE RUDOLF HAPLOCHROMIS SPECIES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>145</tei:p>
         <tei:p>0.5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 2. Haplochromis rudolfianus. Outer row jaw teeth (in labial view) from left<tei:lb/>dentary, anterolateral in position.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>OSTEOLOGY. The neurocranium (Text-fig. 3A) of H. rudolfianus is of the general-<tei:lb/>ized 'H. bloyeti'-type (see Greenwood, 1974), with a moderately decurved profile<tei:lb/>and a relatively short preotic skull length (ca 62-5 per cent of total neurocranial<tei:lb/>length). None of the cephalic laterosensory canals or pores, nor any of the bones<tei:lb/>carrying the canals, is at all hypertrophied (cf. p. 155 ; Text-fig. 36).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 3. Haplochromis rudolfianus. A : Neurocranium, left lateral view.<tei:lb/>B : Bones in the infraorbital series of the right side.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The lower pharyngeal bone (Text-fig. 4) is triangular in outline, with the denti-<tei:lb/>gerous area a little broader than long (ca i-i times). In all specimens examined<tei:lb/>the bone is noticeably stout, especially compared with that of the other Rudolf<tei:lb/>species or that of the generalized species in other lakes and in the east African rivers.<tei:lb/>The degree of enlargement, however, varies between individuals.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>i**</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>146</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The two median tooth rows are composed of teeth clearly stouter than their lateral<tei:lb/>congeners ; the degree of enlargement, like that of the bone itself, shows considerable<tei:lb/>individual variability. All five specimens in the type series have the stoutest bones<tei:lb/>and dentition of all the specimens examined ; the lectotype (51 mm S.L.) is excep-<tei:lb/>tional even amongst the type series in having submolariform teeth posteriorly in<tei:lb/>the median rows (in all other specimens the bicuspid crown is still retained). The<tei:lb/>lectotype also has the relatively most massive lower pharyngeal bone (Text-figs.<tei:lb/>4A and B).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 4. Haplochromis rudolfianus. Lower pharyngeal bones to show variation in size of<tei:lb/>median teeth. A and B : Bone from one of the paratypes, in occlusal and left lateral<tei:lb/>views respectively. C and D : Bone from another specimen of the same size, in occlusal<tei:lb/>and left lateral views respectively.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower pharyngeal bone and tooth enlargement does not seem to be size correlated<tei:lb/>because some of the syntypes are amongst the smaller fishes examined, and a speci-<tei:lb/>men 7 mm longer than the lectotype has a less massive bone and dentition.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vertebral counts in the 30 specimens radiographed are : 27 (fi), 28 (13), 29 (fi8)<tei:lb/>or 30 (f8), comprising n (fi), 12 (14), 13 (123) or 14 (f2) abdominal and 16 (123) or<tei:lb/>17 (17) caudal vertebrae. (The fused first ural and preural centra are not included<tei:lb/>in these figures.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Only two specimens show any sign of fusion or close apposition between elements<tei:lb/>in the hypural series (cf. p. 158) ; in these two fishes the first and second hypurals<tei:lb/>seem to be fused.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VISCERA. The intestine is from i to i| times the standard length ; the ovaries<tei:lb/>are of unequal size with the right ovary noticeably larger than the left in most<tei:lb/>specimens or, rarely, it alone shows signs of oogenesis. A very characteristic feature<tei:lb/>is the intensely melanic tissue of the ovary wall ; the testes, however, are but slightly<tei:lb/>pigmented. The entire peritoneum is also densely melanic. This extreme visceral<tei:lb/>melanism is probably correlated with the intense sunlight to which fishes living in<tei:lb/>the shallows of Lake Rudolf would be subjected.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>LAKE RUDOLF HAPLOCHROMIS SPECIES 147</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COLORATION. In freshly killed specimens of adult male H. rudolftanus the ground<tei:lb/>colour is greenish-yellow (but whitish on the chest). Dark vertical bars cross the<tei:lb/>flank and caudal peduncle (see notes on preserved colours below). Each scale on<tei:lb/>the flanks has an opalescent centre in which yellow, blue and green colours can be<tei:lb/>detected ; yellowish pigment predominates on the anterior body scales, especially<tei:lb/>those around the base of each pectoral fin. Posteriorly on the body the dominant<tei:lb/>colour in the scale centres is electric blue, and is especially noticeable around the<tei:lb/>base of the anal fin. The head, like the anterior part of the body, is an opalescent<tei:lb/>greenish-yellow and blue, the operculum marked with a golden yellow area on its<tei:lb/>lower part. The branchiostegal membrane is a delicate pale yellow except for a<tei:lb/>clearly demarcated black area anteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The dorsal fin membrane is dark golden-yellow, the lappets are scarlet and the<tei:lb/>soft part of the fin has a bright yellow basal streak and light yellow dots dorsally,<tei:lb/>the intervening areas melanic. Black spots also occur on the spinous part of the fin.<tei:lb/>Two dark basal blotches occur on the spinous dorsal ; the first lies between the sixth<tei:lb/>to ninth spines, the second between the last two or three spines. The anal fin is<tei:lb/>yellow but with scattered black and red chromatophores, and with two or three light<tei:lb/>golden-yellow ocelli. The caudal is a marbled yellowish-green, with red and black<tei:lb/>spots, the red colour being most intense in the dorsal and ventral angles of the distal<tei:lb/>margin. The pelvic fins are dusky.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Adult females have a similar but more subdued coloration, with the whitish ventral<tei:lb/>areas more extensive and without the black anterior region to the branchiostegal<tei:lb/>membrane. The pelvic fins are hyaline tinged with yellow, and the red lappets and<tei:lb/>margin to the dorsal and anal fins respectively are barely discernible. On the anal<tei:lb/>fin there are pale yellow spots in the same position as the ocelli of males.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I am indebted to Mr and Mrs Hopson for supplying the notes on which this descrip-<tei:lb/>tion is based.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Preserved coloration is virtually identical in both sexes, except that the pelvics in<tei:lb/>females are clear and not dusky, and the ground coloration is lighter than in males.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The ground coloration is a pale brown (fawn) shading to greyish-charcoal on the<tei:lb/>chest and belly. The flanks and caudal peduncle are crossed by 5-7 (rarely 8-10)<tei:lb/>dark and clearly defined vertical bars ; the bars on the flanks reach almost to the<tei:lb/>ventral profile, but those on the caudal peduncle rarely extend to below the level of<tei:lb/>the midlateral line where they merge with a short and faint horizontal bar extending<tei:lb/>the length of the peduncle. This bar is of variable intensity and is barely visible in<tei:lb/>some specimens. Anteriorly there is a broad, sometimes ill-defined dark bar over-<tei:lb/>lying the cleithrum and following the outline of that bone ; dorsally the bar joins a<tei:lb/>dark, saddle-shaped blotch on the nape. A fainter bar is sometimes visible along the<tei:lb/>vertical limb of the preoperculum. The snout is crossed by a pair of parallel dark<tei:lb/>bars, and there is an intense and clearly demarcated lachrymal stripe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All fins are a greyish-hyaline, the soft dorsal and the entire caudal are maculate,<tei:lb/>the dorsal with two distinct dark blotches basally (see above) , and with dark lappets.<tei:lb/>Spotting on the caudal fin is most distinct proximally, the spots often arranged so as<tei:lb/>to produce two to four dark vertical bands on that part of the fin. The pelvics are<tei:lb/>dusky in males, greyish in females.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>148 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ECOLOGY. Haplochromis rudolfianus is apparently confined to the shallow and<tei:lb/>protected inshore areas of the lake, although there is a population inhabiting a crater<tei:lb/>lake on Central Island (see below}. No data are yet available on the feeding habits<tei:lb/>of this species, nor whether it shows any particular substrate preferences.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Males appear to reach a larger size than do females, and are adult at a standard<tei:lb/>length of 45-47 mm. Females, however, mature at a smaller size, namely ca 30 mm.<tei:lb/>No data are available on the breeding habits or seasons of the species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>THE CENTRAL ISLAND POPULATION. One of the paralectotypes (see p. 142) and 12<tei:lb/>additional specimens collected in 1965 by Dr R. L. Welcomme are from Central<tei:lb/>Island. The paralectotype is apparently from the shore of the island (station<tei:lb/>no. 264, see Worthington, 1932) but the other fishes are from one of the crater lakes<tei:lb/>in that island (see Beadle, 1932, for details of the lakes).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Central Island fishes, particularly those from the crater itself, are of consider-<tei:lb/>able interest since they are apparently isolated from other populations inhabiting<tei:lb/>the mainland shores of the lake. The apparent absence of H. rudolfianus from open-<tei:lb/>water localities suggests that it does not leave (or at least not frequently) its shallow-<tei:lb/>water inshore habitats.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A population of Sarotherodon living in Crater Lake A of Central Island is sufficiently<tei:lb/>distinctive for it to have been referred to a new species (Tilapia vulcani, Trewavas,<tei:lb/>1933, see also Trewavas, 1973, for distinguishing features of the genera Tilapia and<tei:lb/>Sarotherodon) . A population from the neighbouring Crater Lake C, however, did not<tei:lb/>differ significantly from the populations of Sarotherodon niloticus living in the main<tei:lb/>lake (Trewavas, 1933). The explanation for this seemingly anomalous situation<tei:lb/>appears to be that Lake C is, on occasion, connected with the main lake. (Personal<tei:lb/>communication from Dr K. E. Banister, based on information he was given by<tei:lb/>members of the Fishery Research Team on Lake Rudolf ; the last interconnection<tei:lb/>was in 1972.) Lake A, on the other hand, is completely isolated from the main<tei:lb/>lake by a crater wall at least 10 m above current lake level.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is the more regrettable then that the H. rudolfianus collected in 1965 bear no<tei:lb/>more precise locality data than 'Crater Lake, Central Island', and that all are distorted<tei:lb/>and poorly preserved. Allowing for the difficulty of measuring distorted specimens,<tei:lb/>I can find no meristic or morphometric differences between the Central Island fishes<tei:lb/>and those from the main lake. Several of the Island fishes are, however, larger than<tei:lb/>any recorded from the lake (maximum size 72 mm, cf. 58 mm for lake fishes). The<tei:lb/>largest Island fish has four or five unicuspid teeth situated posterolaterally in the<tei:lb/>upper jaw, but this could well be a size-correlated phenomenon (see Greenwood,<tei:lb/>1974). Most of the Island fishes are much darker than are the lake fishes and<tei:lb/>consequently the vertical barring on the body is less obvious ; in a few paler indi-<tei:lb/>viduals, however, the bars are quite distinct. Like their main lake congeners,<tei:lb/>female Crater Lake fishes have only the right ovary well developed, but unlike the<tei:lb/>latter populations the ovarian wall in these fishes is but faintly melanized and then<tei:lb/>only on the dorsal and lateral aspects. These observations were paralleled by those<tei:lb/>I was able to make on specimens and colour photographs obtained by Dr Banister<tei:lb/>during his recent visit to the lake. Once again, the specimens are not well preserved<tei:lb/>and add little anatomico-morphological information to that already available.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>LAKE RUDOLF HAPLOCHROMIS SPECIES 149</tei:p>
         <tei:p>However, the similarity in coloration between Dr Banister's fishes from Crater Lake<tei:lb/>A and those from the Welcomme sample strongly indicate that the latter are from<tei:lb/>the same source.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The dark coloration of Central Island H. rudolfianus seems to parallel that of<tei:lb/>'Tilapia vulcani' from Crater Lake A on the island (see Trewavas, 1933). In other<tei:lb/>characteristics the parallelism is not clearly apparent. That is to say, the H.<tei:lb/>rudolfianus specimens do not show the leanness, larger eyes, larger heads, longer<tei:lb/>dorsal fin spines and broader bands of inner teeth that Trewavas noted in the<tei:lb/>Tilapia specimens (Trewavas, 1933).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In contrast to the Central Island Crater Lake A specimens of H. rudolfianus, the<tei:lb/>paralectotype from the shore of the island does not show any marked darkening of<tei:lb/>the ground coloration. Unfortunately, it is eviscerated so no check can be made on<tei:lb/>the melanization of its gonads. The peritoneum is very dark.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Without more precise locality data, more material from different localities on the<tei:lb/>island and more details on live coloration, little can be said about the taxonomic<tei:lb/>status of Central Island populations of H. rudolfianus. It does, however, seem<tei:lb/>probable that, like the Crater Lake A population of Sar other odon niloticus (with which<tei:lb/>species 'T. vulcani' should now be synonymized ; Dr Trewavas, personal com-<tei:lb/>munication) , the Crater Lake A Haplochromis show some ecophenotypic response to<tei:lb/>their peculiar environment. The relative melanism shown by Crate Lake A Haplo-<tei:lb/>chromis rudolfianus populations is of particular interest because male coloration<tei:lb/>seems to be an important species recognition character (see Greenwood, 1974).<tei:lb/>Altered male coloration apparently is one of the first morphological differences seen<tei:lb/>in recently speciated Haplochromis (Greenwood, 1965).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS AND AFFINITIES OF H. rudolfianus. The distinctively barred colour<tei:lb/>pattern of this species immediately serves to distinguish it from all other Haplo-<tei:lb/>chromis species in Lake Rudolf (see footnote, below). From H. macconneli described<tei:lb/>on p. 154, H. rudolfianus is further distinguished by the absence of hypertrophied<tei:lb/>laterosensory canals and pores on the head, by several morphometric characters (see<tei:lb/>p. 155) and in having few, if any tricuspid teeth in the outer series of either jaw. In<tei:lb/>addition to the hypertrophied canal system, the neurocranium in H. macconneli is of<tei:lb/>a more derived type than that of H. rudolfianus. The nearest living relatives of H.<tei:lb/>rudolfianus are probably H. turkanae (see p. 153), and the fourth but as yet undescribed<tei:lb/>Haplochromis species in the lake. 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The validity of these relationships can only be tested when more material of the<tei:lb/>putative relatives is available.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Four specimens 37-0-64-0 mm standard length (and a fifth prepared as a skeleton) may represent<tei:lb/>a fourth Haplochromis species. Morphometrically these fishes are not distinguishable from H. rudolfianus,<tei:lb/>and the dentition is similar except for there being only a single row of inner teeth in each jaw. The<tei:lb/>principal 'interspecific' difference seems to be in the coloration, both that observed by Mr Hopson (in<tei:lb/>litt.) when the fishes were alive and that remaining in the preserved material. There is also an observable<tei:lb/>(but non-quantifiable) difference in head shape, and these fishes have a colourless (not black) peritoneum.<tei:lb/>The gonads show no sign of melanization, unlike those of H . rudolfianus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All five specimens are from water between 15 and 35 m deep; that is, from somewhat greater depths<tei:lb/>than H. rudolfianus, but within the range of H. turkanae, from which species they differ in the same<tei:lb/>morphometric characters as does H. rudolfianus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Since only five specimens are available and because all are in some way damaged or distorted, I would<tei:lb/>consider it inadvisable to describe a new taxon on this material.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 5. Haplochromis turkanae. Holotype. Drawn by Gordon Howes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In its gross morphology and in the details of its pectoral and predorsal squamation,<tei:lb/>H. rudolfianus resembles H. albertianus Regan, a species endemic to Lake Albert<tei:lb/>(see Trewavas, 1938). The two species differ in their preserved colour patterns, and<tei:lb/>in adult H. albertianus (of the same size as H. rudolfianus) having unicuspid outer jaw<tei:lb/>teeth and a more massive lower pharyngeal bone with a greater number of enlarged,<tei:lb/>submolariform teeth. In other words, H. albertianus shows a greater degree of<tei:lb/>specialization in those characters that are already somewhat specialized in H.<tei:lb/>rudolfianus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>STUDY MATERIAL</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Register number BMNH<tei:lb/>1973.11.13 : 151-154</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1973.11.13 : 155-17</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Locality : Lake Rudolf</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ferguson's Spit (shallow</tei:p>
         <tei:p>water, inshore)<tei:lb/>Topi Point, Allia Bay</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis turkanae sp. nov.<tei:lb/>(Text-figs. 5 and 6)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOLOTYPE. An adult male, 73-0 mm standard length (BMNHreg.no. 1973.11.20:1),<tei:lb/>caught in a bottom trawl fished at a depth of 16 m, over a mud and rock bottom,<tei:lb/>5-6 km north-west of Porr.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PARATYPES. Three adult males (BMNH reg. nos. 1973.11.20 : 2-4), 77-5-86.0 mm<tei:lb/>S.L. from the same locality and trawl as the holotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>LAKE RUDOLF HAPLOCHROMIS SPECIES 151</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Based on these four fishes, 73-0-86-0 mm S.L. With so few<tei:lb/>specimens available most of the morphometric data can be presented most con-<tei:lb/>veniently in tabular form.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>S.L. Depth* Head* PO % IO % Snt % Eye % Cheek % Lj % Uj % CP*</tei:p>
         <tei:p>77'5 35-o<tei:lb/>81-0 34-5<tei:lb/>86-0 33-2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>* = per cent of standard length. % =per cent of head length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PO = preorbital depth; IO = least interorbital width; Snt = snout length; Lj= lower jaw, and Uj :<tei:lb/>upper jaw length. CP = caudal peduncle length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal peduncle 1-4-1-5 times longer than deep. Dorsal profile of head straight<tei:lb/>or gently curved dorsally, but straight anteriorly, sloping at an angle of 30-35<tei:lb/>degrees with the horizontal. The ascending processes of the premaxillae barely<tei:lb/>interrupt the outline of the profile.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mouth slightly (but noticeably) oblique, the lips a little thickened ; posterior tip<tei:lb/>of the maxilla reaching a vertical through the anterior part of the eye. Jaws equal<tei:lb/>anteriorly, the lower 1-6-1-7 times longer than broad. Snout broader than long,<tei:lb/>its anterior profile, when viewed from above, smoothly rounded. None of the<tei:lb/>cephalic laterosensory canals (or their pores) is noticeably enlarged.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gill rakers. Relatively stout, 8 (13) or 9 (fi) on the lower part of the first arch,<tei:lb/>the lowermost one or two rakers reduced in size. Pseudorakers (see p. 143) are<tei:lb/>developed between the inner and outer rows of gill rakers, but are not conspicuous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scales. Ctenoid ; lateral line with 31 (13) or 32 (fi) scales, cheek with 4 (fi) or<tei:lb/>5 (13) imbricating rows. Six or 7 scales between the upper lateral line and the<tei:lb/>dorsal fin origin ; a naked area (about i| scales in extent) immediately before the<tei:lb/>first dorsal fin spine. Nine or 10 scales between the pectoral and pelvic fin bases ;<tei:lb/>the scales of the chest are also very small and grade abruptly with the larger scales<tei:lb/>of the post-pectoral region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fins. Dorsal with 14 (fa) or 15 (f2) spinous rays and 9 (14) branched rays, anal<tei:lb/>with 3 spines and 7 (12) or 8 (12) branched rays. The first pelvic ray is produced,<tei:lb/>very noticeably so in two specimens where it extends as far as the second branched<tei:lb/>anal ray. The caudal fin is strongly subtruncate, almost rounded, and scaled on its<tei:lb/>proximal quarter to half. Pectoral fin 25-6-28-7 per cent of standard length,<tei:lb/>81-5-88-0 per cent of head length.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Teeth. In all four specimens the posterior three or four teeth in the outer pre-<tei:lb/>maxillary row are strong, dagger-like unicuspids. In two fishes the other teeth in<tei:lb/>this row are a mixture of caniniform unicuspids and weakly bicuspids, while in the<tei:lb/>other two specimens distinctly bicuspid teeth predominate, although a few uni-<tei:lb/>cuspids occur anterolaterally. There are 42-52 teeth in this row. There is a similar<tei:lb/>difference in the predominant tooth type of the outer row in the lower jaw. The<tei:lb/>first two specimens have mainly unicuspid teeth with a few bicuspids, the second</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>152</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 6. Haplochromis turkanae. Lower pharyngeal bone of holotype in<tei:lb/>A : occlusal view ; B : left lateral view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pair have a predominance of bicuspids. Bicuspid teeth in the lower jaw have their<tei:lb/>crowns more distinctly incurved than do the upper jaw teeth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bicuspid teeth in both jaws are of the typical generalized Haplochromis type, and<tei:lb/>closely resemble the teeth of H. rudolfianus (see p. 144 ; Text-fig. 2).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The inner series of teeth in both jaws are composed of small tricuspids arranged in<tei:lb/>3 rows in the upper and 2 (or irregularly 2) rows in the lower jaw.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>OSTEOLOGY. With only four specimens available, no skeletal preparations were<tei:lb/>possible. Vertebral counts made from radiographs are : 28 (13) and 29 (fi),<tei:lb/>comprising 13 abdominal and 15 or 16 caudal vertebrae (the fused first preural and<tei:lb/>ural centra not included). No specimen has any fused elements in the caudal fin<tei:lb/>skeleton, but in two fishes hypurals I and 2 are closely apposed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COLORATION. No information is available on the live colours of this species. The<tei:lb/>four adult (but not sexually active) male specimens (fixed in formalin) have a light<tei:lb/>grey to yellowish-grey ground colour that extends ventrally to a clearly demarcated<tei:lb/>horizontal line on the body and caudal peduncle, at which level it becomes pearly<tei:lb/>white. The line is at about the horizontal level of the lowermost insertion of the<tei:lb/>pelvic fin ; thus in lateral view little of the caudal peduncle shows the white ventral<tei:lb/>coloration. On the flanks, most dorsal, lateral and ventrolateral scales have a<tei:lb/>narrow margin of dark pigment. The lower jaw, branchiostegal membrane, sub-<tei:lb/>operculum and the lower part of the cheek are also pearly-white.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>About five very faint vertical dark bars are visible on the flanks, and another may<tei:lb/>also occur posteriorly on the caudal peduncle ; these bars are narrower dorsally<tei:lb/>than ventrally, and do not extend onto the white ventral coloration of the body.<tei:lb/>The vertical limb of the preoperculum is faintly to clearly dusky and there is a broad,<tei:lb/>intensely black lachrymal bar that, at about the level of the posterior maxillary<tei:lb/>tip, narrows abruptly and then continues ventrally and a little medially onto the<tei:lb/>lower jaw.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>LAKE RUDOLF HAPLOCHROMIS SPECIES 153</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The entire soft dorsal fin and the posterior half of the spinous dorsal are densely<tei:lb/>and distinctly spotted, with the spots arranged in from four horizontal rows anteriorly<tei:lb/>to six or more rows posteriorly on the fin. On the anterior part of the spinous dorsal<tei:lb/>the spots are confluent and form vertically aligned, dark, interspinous streaks.<tei:lb/>The lappets of the dorsal fin are black. The entire caudal fin is covered with dark<tei:lb/>and discrete spots so arranged as to form wavy, vertical bars when the fin is not<tei:lb/>fully opened. The anal is hyaline except for three rather pale ocelli. The pel vies<tei:lb/>have the anterior half dusky, the posterior half hyaline ; the elongate first pelvic<tei:lb/>ray is dead- white.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ECOLOGY. Virtually nothing is known about the biology of this species. The<tei:lb/>four specimens came from deeper water than is usual for H . rudolfianus, and shallower<tei:lb/>water than is usual for H. macconneli (see pp. 148 and 159).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All four specimens have the stomach and intestine packed with fragments of<tei:lb/>ostracod shells.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is interesting to note that, unlike H. rudolfianus but like H. macconneli, there is<tei:lb/>no trace of dark pigment in the peritoneum and neither is there any on the gonads<tei:lb/>(cf. p. 146).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All four specimens are adult males, but judging from the size and shape of the<tei:lb/>testes, none is sexually active.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS AND AFFINITIES. Haplochromis turkanae is immediately distinguish-<tei:lb/>able from H. macconneli because of its non-hypertrophied cephalic laterosensory<tei:lb/>canal system. There are also morphometric differences between the species,<tei:lb/>differences in their dentition and, apparently, in the preserved coloration of adult<tei:lb/>males (see below, pp. 156-159).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In its general appearance, its dentition and in several morphometric characters,<tei:lb/>H. turkanae closely resembles H. rudolfianus. It differs principally in having more<tei:lb/>rows of scales on the cheek (4 or 5, cf. 3), smaller scales between the pectoral and<tei:lb/>pelvic fin insertions (9 or 10, cf. 6 or 7), a deeper cheek (26-4-32-0 per cent of head,<tei:lb/>cf. 17-4-25-8, M = 21-7 per cent), longer upper jaw (40-8-41-5, cf. 30-8-38-0, M = 33-7<tei:lb/>percent of head), and a somewhat longer lower jaw (44-0-45-3, cf. 35-7-48-3, M = 39-7<tei:lb/>per cent of head). Haplochromis turkanae also differs in having a more elongate<tei:lb/>first pelvic ray (which is distinctively coloured) and in its overall coloration. For<tei:lb/>example, it lacks the prominent vertical bars on the body, has more intensely and<tei:lb/>densely maculate dorsal and caudal fins, and has the peculiar dribble-like extension<tei:lb/>of the lachrymal bar onto the lower jaw. The lower pharyngeal bone and dentition<tei:lb/>of H. turkanae are somewhat more massive than those of most H. rudolfianus, but<tei:lb/>are quite comparable with those in the type series of that species (see above, p. 146,<tei:lb/>and cf. figs. 4 and 6).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Without more osteological information on H. turkanae it is difficult to say much<tei:lb/>about its affinities with H. rudolfianus. From what is known, however, the two<tei:lb/>species would seem to be very closely related phyletically. Indeed, the resemblance<tei:lb/>parallels that seen between many pairs of Haplochromis species in Lake Victoria.<tei:lb/>As in many of the Victoria pairs there is also an apparent ecological replacement<tei:lb/>involved, with H. rudolfianus being the inshore, shallow-water species and H.<tei:lb/>turkanae the species of deeper waters (see Greenwood, 1974).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>154</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10mm</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 7. Haplochromis macconneli. Holotype. Drawn by Gordon Howes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis macconneli sp. nov.<tei:lb/>(Text-figs. 7-10)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This most distinctive species was discovered by Mr and Mrs A. J. Hopson when the<tei:lb/>Lake Rudolf Research Project team began trawling operations in the deeper waters<tei:lb/>of the lake. Apparently it is confined to water more than 20 m deep and has been<tei:lb/>collected from depths down to 75 m.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Besides its various anatomical peculiarities, H. macconneli is also noteworthy for<tei:lb/>its marked sexual dimorphism in adult size. No males larger than 35-5 mm standard<tei:lb/>length have yet been recorded. Indeed, despite intensive efforts, only two males<tei:lb/>have so far been recognized amongst the several hundreds of specimens examined.<tei:lb/>Females, on the other hand, are common components of deep-water trawl catches.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The taxon is named for Mr R. B. McConnel, Officer in Charge of the Fisheries<tei:lb/>Department at Lake Rudolf, in grateful recognition of the assistance he has un-<tei:lb/>stintingly given to Mr Hopson and his research team.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOLOTYPE. A female, 77-0 mm standard length (BMNH reg. no. 1973.11.13 : 37),<tei:lb/>caught near the bottom in 50-64 m of water 3 miles north-west of Central Island.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PARATYPES. (i) Twenty-one specimens (BMNH reg. nos. 1973.11.13 : 38-58),<tei:lb/>51-0-72-0 mm S.L., all females and from the same locality as the holotype ; (ii) 6<tei:lb/>juveniles (of indeterminable sex), 22-0-38-0 mm S.L., caught in a bottom trawl at a<tei:lb/>depth of 20 m 1-6 km off Ferguson's Spit (BMNH reg. nos. 1973.11.13 : 59-64 ;<tei:lb/>(iii) 2 adult males, 31-0 and 35-5 mm S.L., caught in a bottom trawl at a depth of<tei:lb/>30 m, 2-4 km east of North Island (BMNH reg. nos. 1973.11.13 : 65-66).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Based on the holotype and 29 paratypes, 22-0-77-0 mm S.L.<tei:lb/>Various characters have been checked on the 78 additional specimens (size range<tei:lb/>15-0-59-0 mm S.L.) from the Ferguson's Spit station and one other station 3-2 km</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>LAKE RUDOLF HAPLOCHROMIS SPECIES 155</tei:p>
         <tei:p>off-shore at a depth of 75 m. None of this extra material has, however, been in-<tei:lb/>cluded in the morphometric counts and measurements.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Because most of the proportional measurements used in this description show<tei:lb/>allometry with the fish's size, the material has been divided into two size groups,<tei:lb/>one of fishes 51-77 mm S.L. and the other of fishes 22-38 mm S.L. Ranges and<tei:lb/>means for the larger specimens (N = 22) are given first, followed in parentheses<tei:lb/>by those for the smaller fishes (N = 8).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Length of head 33'3-39'9, M = 35-3 (31-6-39-4, M = 36-0) per cent of standard<tei:lb/>length, depth of body 317-35-1. M = 33'3 (25-3-32-3. M = 2 97) P er cent -</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dorsal profile of head clearly but gently concave above the eye, sloping at an angle<tei:lb/>of ca 35-40 degrees to the horizontal. The profile of the snout varies from straight<tei:lb/>to somewhat decurved, with the premaxillary pedicels always breaking the outline.<tei:lb/>The anterior tip of the lower jaw is usually produced into a symphysial knob, which<tei:lb/>is most obvious in fishes over 65 mm S.L.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An outstanding feature of the head (in specimens of all sizes) is the greatly enlarged<tei:lb/>openings to all the laterosensory canals (Text-figs. 7 and 9). Particularly obvious<tei:lb/>are those on the preorbital and preopercular bones. The underlying canals are<tei:lb/>hypertrophied, with the result that the bones involved have a distinctly inflated<tei:lb/>appearance.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Laterosensory canals on the neurocrariium, especially the temporal canal of the<tei:lb/>pterotic bone, are also inflated, particularly in comparison with those in H. rudol-<tei:lb/>fianus and H. turkanae, and indeed with those of the generality of Haplochromis<tei:lb/>species (see below, p. 158). Canals, and their openings, in the extrascapular and<tei:lb/>supracleithrum are equally affected by this trend, as are the nasals although the<tei:lb/>latter are relatively the least cavernous of the cephalic laterosensory canal bones.<tei:lb/>In well-preserved specimens the canal openings are occluded by a thin mem-<tei:lb/>brane.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Depth of preorbital 16-6-22-2, M = 20-1 (12-5-16-7, M = 15-4) per cent of head,<tei:lb/>least interorbital width 18-8-24-2, M = 21-8 (14-7-25-0, M = 21-2) per cent. Snout<tei:lb/>slightly broader than long (rarely as long as broad) in specimens of all sizes, its length<tei:lb/>27-8-38-1, M = 33-8 (26-1-33-3, M = 29-6) per cent of head for the size groups<tei:lb/>respectively. Diameter of eye 23-7-29-3, M = 26-8 (25-0-33-3, M = 28-7) and depth<tei:lb/>of cheek 22-8-29-3, M = 26-7 (i8-i-25'-o, M = 21-2) per cent of head.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caudal peduncle 16-5-21-5, M = 18-6 (17-8-22-6, M = 20-0) per cent of standard<tei:lb/>length, 1-5-2-2 times as long as deep in fishes of all sizes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower jaw with a distinct symphysial knob in fishes of all sizes, the protuberance<tei:lb/>most marked in individuals of &gt; 65 mm S.L. Length of lower jaw 40-8-51-0,<tei:lb/>M = 45-6 (37-6-46-2, M = 42-0) per cent of head, 1-6-2-0 (modal range 1-8-2-0)<tei:lb/>times longer than broad in specimens of all sizes. Length of upper jaw 31-8-44-0,<tei:lb/>M = 38-4 (30-6-37-6, M = 33-3) per cent of head.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mouth slightly oblique, the posterior tip of the maxilla reaching a vertical through<tei:lb/>the anterior margin of the orbit, or to a point slightly posterior to that line.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gill rakers. Of variable form, but usually with the upper 2 or 3 rakers on the first<tei:lb/>gill arch flattened and branched, those on the middle section of the arch relatively<tei:lb/>slender, and the lowermost I or 2 rakers reduced ; no pseudorakers are developed</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>156 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 8. Haplochromis macconneli. Dentition. A : Outer teeth from the premaxilla.<tei:lb/>B : Outer teeth from the dentary. In both, the teeth are from an anterolateral position<tei:lb/>in the jaw and are viewed labially.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(see p. 143). There are 7 (fi), 8 (f8) or 9 (121) rakers on the lower limb of the first gill<tei:lb/>arch.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scales. Ctenoid, those on the chest very small but grading in size with those on<tei:lb/>the subpectoral region (that is, the demarcation between small and large scales in<tei:lb/>this region is less abrupt than in H. rudolfianus ; see p. 154).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Five and a half to 7 (mode 6) scales between the dorsal fin origin and the lateral<tei:lb/>line, 7-9 (modes 8 and 9), rarely 5, between the pectoral and pelvic fin bases. Cheek<tei:lb/>with 3 or 4 rows of imbricating scales. In most specimens there is a small naked area<tei:lb/>(about the area of one scale) in front of the first dorsal fin spine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fins. Dorsal with 22 (f6), 23 (fi6) or 24 (f8) rays, comprising 13 (12), 14 (fi6),<tei:lb/>15 (fn) or 16 (fi) spinous and 8 (fn), 9 (fi8) or 10 (fi) branched rays. Anal with<tei:lb/>3 spines and 7 (f2), 8 (25) or 9 (13) branched rays. First ray of the pelvic fin slightly<tei:lb/>produced, more so in larger fishes. Caudal truncate, scaled on its proximal quarter<tei:lb/>(mode) to third. Pectoral fin 25-8-34-5, M = 28-6 (23-7-28-3, M = 26-1) per cent<tei:lb/>of standard length, and 73-0-92-5, M = 81-1 (63-5-77-0, M = 72-3) per cent of head.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Teeth. In fishes more than 50 mm S.L. the outer row of premaxillary teeth is<tei:lb/>composed of unequally bicuspid teeth anteriorly, but of tricuspids laterally and<tei:lb/>posteriorly (Text-fig. 8) ; the median cusp of the tricuspids, and the major cusp of the<tei:lb/>bicuspids is slightly incurved. Many specimens have some tricuspids intercalated<tei:lb/>amongst the biscuspids anteriorly, and in a few fishes almost the entire outer row is<tei:lb/>composed of tricuspid teeth. When there is a mixture of bi- and tricuspids the latter<tei:lb/>predominate. At all positions in the tooth row the bi- and tricuspids are of equal<tei:lb/>size.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tooth morphology and arrangement in the lower jaw are similar to those in the<tei:lb/>upper, although more individuals have only tricuspid teeth present ; a predominantly<tei:lb/>bicuspid outer row is rarely encountered.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fishes in the size range 20-40 mm S.L. have mainly bicuspid teeth in the upper<tei:lb/>jaw, with those tricuspids present restricted to a posterolateral position in the row.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>LAKE RUDOLF HAPLOCHROMIS SPECIES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>157</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. g. Haplochromis macconneli. A : Neurocranium in right lateral view. B : Neuro-<tei:lb/>cranium, dorsal surface. C : Bones of the infraorbital series, right side. D : Right lower<tei:lb/>jaw, viewed from a slightly ventrolateral position.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bicuspid teeth also predominate in the lower jaw, but some unicuspid (and slender)<tei:lb/>teeth may occur posterolaterally. Tooth form is like that of the larger fishes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are 41-64 (M = 52) outer premaxillary teeth in fishes 50-77 mm S.L., and<tei:lb/>24-42 in specimens 22-39 mm long.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Irrespective of a fish's size, the inner teeth in both jaws are all tricuspid and small,<tei:lb/>and are usually arranged in a single series but double rows are encountered occasion-<tei:lb/>ally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>OSTEOLOGY. The characteristic hypertrophy in the cephalic laterosensory canal<tei:lb/>system has been commented upon above (see also Text-figs. 7 and 9). Canal bones<tei:lb/>in the pectoral skeleton are also affected, and the otic region of the skull is noticeably<tei:lb/>inflated (see Text-fig. 9).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The neurocranium (Text-fig. 9) departs from the generalized Haplochromis type<tei:lb/>(as seen in H. mdolfianus, Text-fig. 3) and clearly approaches that found in H.<tei:lb/>saxicola and allied species in the Lake Victoria species flock (Greenwood, 1974). In<tei:lb/>other words, the preotic region of the skull is slightly more elongate than in the<tei:lb/>generalized type, and associated with this and the shallower braincase, the preotic<tei:lb/>skull roof is straighter and slopes upwards at a smaller angle. The supraoccipital</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>158</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>crest is lower than in most generalized types of skull, and the otic region is narrower.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although all the canal bones of the skull (and also those bones encasing the inner<tei:lb/>ear) are noticeably inflated, the dermopterotics show the greatest hypertrophy of all<tei:lb/>(see Text-fig. gA and B).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The lower pharyngeal bone (Text-fig. 10) is triangular in outline (length and breadth<tei:lb/>of the dentigerous surface almost equal), is relatively slender, and has an anterior<tei:lb/>blade that is neither noticeably long nor noticeably short. The teeth on this bone<tei:lb/>are rather sparsely arranged in 16-20 irregular rows. Without exception, the teeth<tei:lb/>are weakly bicuspid, with a low, blunt or even barely visible anterior cusp and a<tei:lb/>crown that slopes gently into the sharper and larger posterior cusp ; all are fine and<tei:lb/>compressed but those in the two median rows are somewhat coarser.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>FIG. 10. Haplochromis macconneli. Lower pharyngeal bone in occlusal view.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vertebrae and the caudal fin skeleton. Vertebral counts for the 24 specimens<tei:lb/>radiographed are : 27 (fi), 28 (f8), 29 (fi4) or 30 (fi), comprising 12 (fi6) or 13 (f8)<tei:lb/>abdominal and 15 (fi), 16 (fi5) or 17 (f8) caudal centra. The fused first ural and<tei:lb/>first preural centra are excluded from these counts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The caudal fin skeleton is unusual in showing a high degree of fusion between<tei:lb/>various hypurals (or if not fusion, such extremely close apposition as to be in-<tei:lb/>distinguishable from fusion on radiographed specimens). The extent of fusion or<tei:lb/>apposition is generally complete, but in a few fishes there are short unfused sections<tei:lb/>between the otherwise conjoined elements.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>About 77 per cent of the 26 specimens radiographed showed some degree of fusion<tei:lb/>between various hypurals. Only 6 specimens (ca 23 per cent of the sample) had all<tei:lb/>5 hypurals completely free from each other. Most frequently (i.e. in 20 fishes)<tei:lb/>hypurals I and 2 are fused. In the upper part of the skeleton the commonest<tei:lb/>pattern of fusion is to have hypurals 3 and 4 fused, but hypural 5 free (n specimens) ;<tei:lb/>only 4 specimens had all 3 upper hypurals fused, and 5 fishes showed no fusion<tei:lb/>between any of the 3 upper hypurals. In H. rudolfianus, it will be recalled, only 2<tei:lb/>out of 30 specimens (i.e. about 7 per cent) had any fused hypurals ; in both these<tei:lb/>fishes fusion was between hypurals i and 2 (see p. 146).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>LAKE RUDOLF HAPLOCHROMIS SPECIES 159</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For comparison with the situation in Lake Rudolf, the caudal skeleton in several<tei:lb/>endemic Haplochromis species from other lakes was examined. Of 174 specimens<tei:lb/>(representing 12 species) from Lake George, Uganda, about 8 per cent showed some<tei:lb/>(but never complete) fusion between elements in both the upper and the lower parts<tei:lb/>of the skeleton. The frequency of fusion seems equally distributed amongst the<tei:lb/>species examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In Lake Victoria, too, hypural fusion is relatively rare. One hundred and<tei:lb/>seventy-eight specimens representing 22 species (with a modal sample size of 10<tei:lb/>specimens per species) were examined. Of these, 20 specimens (i.e. about 13 per<tei:lb/>cent) had fused hypurals. The commonest pattern here is of fusion between hy-<tei:lb/>purals 3 and 4, less frequently it occurs between hypurals i and 2, and only once was<tei:lb/>it recorded, with certainty, between hypurals i and 2, and 3 and 4 in the same<tei:lb/>individual (although two other individuals may show this pattern). The Lake<tei:lb/>Victoria species examined are from several phyletic lineages within the Haplochromis<tei:lb/>flock of that lake and cover a wide range of body forms.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Far fewer specimens are available of the four endemic Haplochromis species from<tei:lb/>Lake Albert. Of these, H . bullatus Trewavas has 3 out of 18 fishes (i.e. about 17 per<tei:lb/>cent) with hypurals i and 2 fused (or very closely apposed), while H. avium Regan<tei:lb/>(9 specimens) and H. albertianus Regan (15 specimens) have none. Both the latter<tei:lb/>species, however, have some individuals in which the hypurals are closely apposed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thus, even allowing for the small sample sizes involved in this survey, it does<tei:lb/>seem that the frequency of hypural fusion in H, macconneli is exceptionally high.<tei:lb/>The significance of this phenomenon remains unexplained.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VISCERA. Because of poor preservation it is impossible to measure precisely the<tei:lb/>length of the gut in H. macconneli ; I would estimate the intestine to be about i^<tei:lb/>times longer than the standard length. In strong contrast to H. rudolfianus there is<tei:lb/>no trace of melanin in the peritoneal tissue and neither are the gonadial walls pig-<tei:lb/>mented (see p. 146 above).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COLORATION. In life, adult females are a pale greenish-fawn with traces of greenish<tei:lb/>iridescence on the flanks. All fins are colourless except for three conspicuous and<tei:lb/>bright yellow spots on the anal.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Live colours for males have not been recorded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Preserved colours. I suspect that the material I have examined is somewhat<tei:lb/>bleached and thus the coloration is probably lighter than it might otherwise have<tei:lb/>been.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There is apparently little sexual dichromatism. In both sexes the ground colour<tei:lb/>of the body and head is a pale yellowish-fawn with no tonal variation between dorsum<tei:lb/>and venter. All fins are hyaline with, in both sexes, dark maculations on the proxi-<tei:lb/>mal third to half of the caudal fin. The males examined have the dorsal fin somewhat<tei:lb/>darker than that of the females, and there is a fairly dense aggregation of melano-<tei:lb/>phores on the anterior third of the pelvic fins. (These specimens may, however, be<tei:lb/>less bleached than are the females.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ECOLOGY. Judging from Mr Hopson's records, H. macconneli is confined to water<tei:lb/>more than 20 m deep, and is probably most abundant in deeper water (i.e. at depths</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>160 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>of 50-70 m). Some of the smallest specimens collected (15-20 mm S.L.) were<tei:lb/>caught at a depth of 75 m, and none, of any size, has been recorded from littoral<tei:lb/>habitats. The pale coloration of this species and the absence of melanic pigments<tei:lb/>in the peritoneum and gonads may well be correlated with this deep-water distribu-<tei:lb/>tion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No data are available yet on the feeding habits of the species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Breeding biology. The marked sexual dimorphism in adult size has been noted<tei:lb/>already (p. 154). Despite a very thorough search, Mr and Mrs Hopson were at first<tei:lb/>unable to find any males amongst the several hundreds of H. macconneli they ex-<tei:lb/>amined. Eventually two males, 31-0 and 35-5 mm S.L., were identified in a catch<tei:lb/>made some 2-4 km east of North Island at a depth of 30 m. Both these fishes<tei:lb/>appear to be sexually adult ; one is probably in an advanced stage of ripening, the<tei:lb/>other at a slightly earlier stage of development. Females are certainly adult at a<tei:lb/>length of ca 50 mm and it seems likely that they may mature at a smaller size<tei:lb/>(Hopson in litt.}. Be that as it may, females seem to grow to a much greater length<tei:lb/>than do males.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In a sample of 21 adult females examined, only 2 have both ovaries equally<tei:lb/>developed. Eleven fishes have the right ovary much larger than the left one (at all<tei:lb/>stages of oogenesis), and 8 have only the right ovary developed. Unlike H. rudolfi-<tei:lb/>anus, there is no trace of melanization in the ovarian wall of H. macconneli.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No details are available on the breeding habits or seasons of the species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS AND AFFINITIES. Haplochromis macconneli is readily distinguished<tei:lb/>from the other Lake Rudolf species by the hypertrophy of its cephalic laterosensory<tei:lb/>canal system, its dentition (see p. 156), and in specimens &gt; 35 mrn S.L., from H.<tei:lb/>rudolfianus by several morphometric characters (deeper cheek and preorbital,<tei:lb/>longer snout, smaller eye and longer jaws).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Indeed, H. macconneli is so distinct morphologically from H. rudolfianus and<tei:lb/>H. turkanae (and the putative fourth species) that it is difficult to establish its phyletic<tei:lb/>affinities with these other taxa. In addition to the characters listed above, H.<tei:lb/>macconneli also differs from H. rudolfianus (and from the undescribed species too)<tei:lb/>in the shape of its neurocranium, which is of a more specialized type (see above,<tei:lb/>p. 157 and Greenwood, 1974). Almost certainly the hypertrophy of the cephalic<tei:lb/>lateral line canals is an adaptation associated with the deep-water habitat of H.<tei:lb/>macconneli, and strongly suggests that the species evolved within the lake. No<tei:lb/>fluviatile Haplochromis exhibits this specialization.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is interesting to note that the cephalic lateral line canal hypertrophy seen in<tei:lb/>H. macconneli is much greater than that found in any known Haplochromis species<tei:lb/>living at comparable depths in Lake Victoria (Greenwood &amp; Gee, 1969). Amongst<tei:lb/>Haplochromis-gToup species an equivalent hypertrophy is seen only in H. bullatus<tei:lb/>of Lake Albert, and in species of the endemic Lake Malawi genus Trematocranus<tei:lb/>(Trewavas, 1935). Species of another Malawi endemic, Aulonocara, show greater<tei:lb/>development in certain parts of the system (the infraorbital series for example), but<tei:lb/>otherwise exhibit a level of hypertrophy comparable with that of H. macconneli.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trematocranus and Aulonocara are manifestly more closely related to each other<tei:lb/>and to other taxa from Lake Malawi (Trewavas, 1935 ; personal observations) than</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>LAKE RUDOLF HAPLOCHROMIS SPECIES 161</tei:p>
         <tei:p>to any species occurring outside the lake. Neither need be considered further in the<tei:lb/>possible phylogeny of H. macconneli.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>On purely morphological grounds H. bullatus of Lake Albert could be considered<tei:lb/>the nearest living relative of H. macconneli. Both species share the specialization<tei:lb/>of enlarged laterosensory canals on the head, and both share (with other species from<tei:lb/>Lakes Albert and Rudolf) certain peculiarities in the predorsal and thoracic squama-<tei:lb/>tion patterns (see above, p. 144). The latter character is, however, difficult to assess<tei:lb/>with respect to its being a primitive or a derived one. At present all that can be<tei:lb/>said is that the pattern is not encountered amongst the Haplochromis species of<tei:lb/>Lake Victoria nor is it seen in the fluviatile Haplochromis of Kenya, Uganda and<tei:lb/>Tanzania. It is rarely encountered in the Haplochromis species flock of Lakes<tei:lb/>Edward and George (where it is known from two species, H. pharyngalis Poll and<tei:lb/>H. petronius Greenwood ; see Greenwood, 1973), but it does seem to characterize<tei:lb/>the Haplochromis of the River Nile, Lake Albert, Lake Rudolf and the River Zaire<tei:lb/>(personal observations ; also Greenwood, 1971).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haplochromis macconneli differs from H . bullatus in the shape of its neurocranium<tei:lb/>(see p. 157 above) which is like that found in the moderately specialized insectivore-<tei:lb/>piscivore radiation in Lake Victoria (see Greenwood, 1974, pp. 80-93). This<tei:lb/>difference would not, of course, debar H. bullatus from consideration as the living<tei:lb/>plesiomorph sister species of H. macconneli. But the fact that the Lake Rudolf<tei:lb/>and Lake Albert basins have never been interconnected (and if there had been some<tei:lb/>riverine connection, the probability that any presumed common ancestor of the two<tei:lb/>species would itself have been abyssal in habits) seems to rule out any such close<tei:lb/>phyletic relationship. Interspecific similarities in laterosensory canal hypertrophy<tei:lb/>are thus to be interpreted as the product of parallel evolution. The shared peculiari-<tei:lb/>ties in squamation patterns may well reflect a common ancestry but this is likely to<tei:lb/>be a relatively distant one (see below, p. 162).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It seems probable, therefore, that the relationships of H. macconneli should be<tei:lb/>sought amongst the species of Lake Rudolf. Two interpretations seem possible.<tei:lb/>First, H. macconneli may be an immediate derivative of an H. rudolfianus-like<tei:lb/>ancestor (i.e. H. rudolfianus and H. macconneli may be true sister species). Alter-<tei:lb/>natively, H. macconneli might be the apomorph survivor of another lineage the<tei:lb/>relatively plesiomorph, that is H. rudolfianus-like members of which have become<tei:lb/>extinct (unlike the situation in Lake Victoria, for example, where it is possible to<tei:lb/>follow, from species still extant, the specialization of a lineage ; see Greenwood,<tei:lb/>1974).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Even with the discovery of two and possibly three new Haplochromis species, the<tei:lb/>total fish fauna of Lake Rudolf still stands low on the scale of endemicity in African<tei:lb/>lakes. Its Haplochromis species flock also shows a low level of adaptive radiation,<tei:lb/>probably lower than that of Lake Albert (see Trewavas, 1938 ; Greenwood, 1971)<tei:lb/>where an anatomically specialized mollusc-eater, a specialized grazer on epiphytes<tei:lb/>and a species adapted for life in deep water have evolved.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>162 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This comparison must, however, be interpreted with care. For one thing, H.<tei:lb/>mahagiensis David &amp; Poll (the mollusc-crushing species) of Lake Albert may well<tei:lb/>belong to a different lineage from that of the other species in the lake. It could be<tei:lb/>the local representative of a fluviatile mollusc-crushing species represented elsewhere<tei:lb/>by H. straeleni Poll and H. vanderhorsti Greenwood (see Greenwood, 1954 &amp; iQSQa, for<tei:lb/>discussion). Furthermore, a temporal element is probably involved. There is little<tei:lb/>evidence of Lake Albert having dried out at any time in its history, but Lake Rudolf<tei:lb/>probably was severely reduced, or even completely desiccated, during the middle<tei:lb/>part of the Pleistocene (see Fryer &amp; lies, 1972, for review). Refilling of the Rudolf<tei:lb/>basin appears to have been through what is now the River Sobat at some time within<tei:lb/>the later Pleistocene. Subsequently the connection was broken and has never been<tei:lb/>re-established. Such an historical background has two consequences, namely that<tei:lb/>Lake Rudolf is to be considered a relatively young lake, and that its colonizers (or,<tei:lb/>perhaps more accurately, its recolonizers) were species of Nilotic origin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The relative youth of Lake Rudolf, coupled with the nature of its basin may, as<tei:lb/>Fryer &amp; lies (1972) suggest, account for the paucity of endemic species and, I would<tei:lb/>also suggest, for the muted adaptive radiation seen amongst the three or four<tei:lb/>Haplochromis species that evolved there.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>With two exceptions, all the Haplochromis species of Lake Albert are apparently<tei:lb/>confined to the basin of that lake. The two more widely distributed species, H.<tei:lb/>wingatii (Blgr.) and H. loati Greenwood, both have dental specializations that are<tei:lb/>not shared with any Lake Rudolf taxa (Greenwood, 1971). Thus, it seems unlikely<tei:lb/>that an extant Albertine Haplochromis species was the original recolonizer of Lake<tei:lb/>Rudolf in later Pleistocene times. Nor does it seem probable that the recolonizer<tei:lb/>closely resembled any species from the Nile (amongst which must be considered H,<tei:lb/>wingatii and H. loati or their ancestors). In this situation the only conclusion that<tei:lb/>can be drawn is that some fluviatile species, now extinct, provided the founder<tei:lb/>population for the Lake Rudolf microflock.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is, of course, possible that the present-day Rudolf species (or some part of them)<tei:lb/>are descendants from the relicts of a previous flock, possibly a more complex one,<tei:lb/>that inhabited the early Pleistocene lake and which survived the subsequent period<tei:lb/>of desiccation. The neurocranial differences between H. rudolftanus and H. maccon-<tei:lb/>neli might be explained in this way. If this was the history of the present-day<tei:lb/>species then it follows that their ancestors were derived not from the Nile (which<tei:lb/>did not then exist in its present form ; see Berry &amp; Whiteman, 1968), but from a<tei:lb/>river that originated in the eastern highlands and emptied into the developing Nile<tei:lb/>system in the region of the present River Sobat.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shared peculiarities in the squamation pattern of the thoracic and predorsal<tei:lb/>regions hint at a common ancestry for the Lake Rudolf and Lake Albert Haplochromis<tei:lb/>species (see above, p. 161). This character complex is not found in the H. bloyeti-like<tei:lb/>species group that is widespread in the rivers of Uganda, Kenya and Tanzania.<tei:lb/>Members of this species complex are thought to be close relatives of the ancestral<tei:lb/>species which gave rise to the sister species flocks in Lake Victoria and Lakes<tei:lb/>Edward and George (see Greenwood, 1973 &amp; 1974). Fishes in these flocks, with one<tei:lb/>exception in Lake George and one in Lake Edward, all lack the Albert-Rudolf scale</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>LAKE RUDOLF HAPLOCHROMIS SPECIES 163</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pattern. The exceptional species, H. petronius and H. pharyngalis, resemble the<tei:lb/>Nilotic H. wingatii in several features as well as the one of scale pattern, and they<tei:lb/>may represent an exotic element amongst the otherwise H. bloyeti-like. derivatives<tei:lb/>inhabiting these lakes (Greenwood, 1974). The possible phyletic relationship of<tei:lb/>Haplochromis species from Lakes Rudolf and Albert raises some interesting points<tei:lb/>of zoogeography. The lakes are several hundred kilometres apart and any form of<tei:lb/>past interconnection they may have had would have been of an indirect nature (see<tei:lb/>above, p. 162). In contrast, Lake Albert is close to Lake Edward and the lakes are<tei:lb/>in direct contact through the River Semliki. Yet, their faunas, both cichlid and<tei:lb/>non-cichlid, are quite distinct (Greenwood, 1959^. The present barrier to faunal<tei:lb/>interchange, principally the Semliki rapids, is clearly an effective one.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I have argued elsewhere for a close phyletic relationship between the Haplochromis<tei:lb/>species of Lakes Edward and Victoria and for their derivation in parallel from a<tei:lb/>common ancestor that once inhabited the westward flowing rivers of eastern Africa<tei:lb/>during the Pleistocene (Greenwood, 1973). It seems now that perhaps this concept<tei:lb/>should be qualified by postulating an ancestral species that lived in some but not<tei:lb/>all of those rivers. The reasoning behind this qualification is, of course, the presence<tei:lb/>of species in Lake Albert that would seem to be derived from a different lineage, a<tei:lb/>lineage that also gave rise to the species of the Nile and, possibly, Lake Rudolf as<tei:lb/>well (see above, p. 161). Furthermore, it is possible that the Haplochromis species<tei:lb/>of the River Zaire may share ancestry with these species (p. 161).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The evidence upon which these postulated phylogenies are based, a shared scale<tei:lb/>pattern, is admittedly tenuous, particularly since it is not yet possible to determine<tei:lb/>which of the two types is to be considered the primitive condition. Further research<tei:lb/>is planned to investigate the phylogeny of Haplochromis-group species and I would<tei:lb/>certainly not consider the ideas expressed here as more than a working hypothesis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The presence of two species with Albert-Rudolf scale patterns (H. petronius and<tei:lb/>H. pharyngalis) in Lakes George and Edward demands explanation. Three pos-<tei:lb/>sible explanations can be considered. First, the ancestor of these species made its<tei:lb/>way into the Lake Edward basin in fairly recent times and via the River Semliki.<tei:lb/>The likelihood of this, however, is reduced by the fact that no reciprocal exchange of<tei:lb/>Haplochromis seems to have taken place (although the two lakes share another<tei:lb/>cichlid Sar other odon leucostictus [Trewavas]). Second, the prerift rivers each may<tei:lb/>have contained species of both squamation types. The absence of species with the<tei:lb/>Albert-Rudolf pattern from most rivers in eastern Africa (and probably from Lake<tei:lb/>Victoria as well) would seem unlikely if both types had been represented there<tei:lb/>previously. The third possibility is one based on the assumption of there having<tei:lb/>been a single basin in which the proto-Lakes Albert and Edward developed, probably<tei:lb/>as a series of partly interconnected small and swampy lakes. The northern region<tei:lb/>of this basin (the future Lake Albert) could have been fed by rivers in which the<tei:lb/>Haplochromis species had an Albert-Rudolf facies, while the southern end (future<tei:lb/>Lakes Edward and George) was fed by rivers with Haplochromis of a Victoria-Edward<tei:lb/>facies. The next assumption would be that only a limited exchange of species took<tei:lb/>place between the two regions before their continuity was broken. Victoria-type<tei:lb/>species, if any penetrated to the north, were, presumably, unsuccessful in that</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>164 P. H. GREENWOOD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>environment or in competition with the Albert-Rudolf types. Such a general<tei:lb/>contact between the early lakes may also account for the similarity in their Pleisto-<tei:lb/>cene fish faunas (see Greenwood, I95gb ; also new and unpublished observations),<tei:lb/>although one can equally argue that a fauna of this type was widespread in the<tei:lb/>prerift river systems.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Whatever the explanation, it does seem that both Lake Albert and Lake Rudolf<tei:lb/>have, since their inceptions, been relatively isolated from each other and from other<tei:lb/>water bodies in eastern Africa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I am particularly grateful to Mr and Mrs A. J. Hopson for, in the first place, sending<tei:lb/>me the specimens on which this paper is based, and then for the great pains they took<tei:lb/>to obtain extra information and specimens. To my colleague Mr Gordon Howes<tei:lb/>goes my gratitude for all the help he has given in the preparation of the paper, for<tei:lb/>his draughtsmanship displayed in Text-figs. 5, 7 and 8, and for his skill in radio-<tei:lb/>graphing several hundred specimens. Finally, I thank my colleague Dr Keith<tei:lb/>Banister whose visit to Lake Rudolf (made since this paper went to press) led to his<tei:lb/>providing me with valuable extra information on Crater Lake species, and on the<tei:lb/>scarcity of H. macconneli males ; despite diligent searches he found none of the<tei:lb/>latter.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REFERENCES</tei:p>
